title: What is the difference between maths and philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is a joke that goes as follows: Math Departments are cheap because all a mathematician needs is a pencil, paper and a wastebasket. Philosophy departments are even cheaper because you can skip the wastebasket. Although I think there is a grain of truth in this joke, I also feel it portrays philosophy in a far harsher light than it deserves. Post-modern deconstructionism, after all, constitutes only a very small portion of philosophy. Consider first what many mathematicians and philosophers do have in common: A love for knowledge, truth and reasonA dedication to clarity of thoughtA field of research which requires a lot of abstract thought, and a kind of abstract creativityAn appreciation for well-reasoned argumentsA commitment to question and especially identify hidden assumptions in argumentsIn some areas like formal philosophy, philosophy of physics, foundations of probability and philosophy mathematics, the activities of philosophers become increasingly mathematical, although the formal or mathematical methods are usually in the service of a goal that is primarily philosophical, rather than mathematical, in nature. To give a concrete example, I recently ran into this paper by the well-known philosopher of physics, David Malament, who published it in the Journal of Mathematical Physics and which is essentially indistinguishable from a work a mathematician might have written: https://aip.scitation.org/doi/abs/10.1063/1.523436 However, most areas of philosophy are far less mathematical, presenting arguments in the form of natural language. If I had to pin down the difference between philosophy and mathematics to one thing it would be this: Mathematicians work towards the goal of finding true answers to certain questions, while for philosophers that is (often) not the primary goal. The high degree of formalism and rigor in mathematics is not an end to itself, it is a means to ensure that the definite answer one reaches is correct. More than in any other field, it is possible in mathematics to unequivocally determine whether certain definite statements are true or false. Other fields, even the sciences, can only dream of this power of mathematics. For philosophers, it would be nice to find an unequivocally true definite answer to some philosophical problem, but it is in the nature of many philosophical conundra that they do not lend themselves to the kind of methods which yield definite and true answers. It should therefore not be surprising that many philosophical problems have been around for as long as millenia. Consider, for instance, a question that is actually part of my research: What, concretely, do we mean by “existence”? How can one even begin to apply mathematical methods to something as open-ended as this? Clearly, one has to start with some basic assumptions, and already here disagreement (sometimes of the wild kind!) rears its head. Some philosophers think “being” and “existing” are the same, many do not; Some think “existence” can be considered a predicate, others do not, some think “possible worlds” different from ours “exist” on an equal footing as ours, others do not, and so on. In addition, the arguments may often involve nuances which are finer than what is possible to express in the language of mathematics. So, even if you just consider a particular philosophical theory and want to follow the mathematical path, you still have to translate it into that language, which can be another source of vehement disagreement because inevitably there is more than one way to formalize a highly nuanced concept. Even if you manage to get your philosophical theory through these stages, you may find that it gives you definite answers, but ones which are completely counter to common intuitions. See, for example, section 4 of this article on Deontic Logic which discusses some “paradoxes” which arise from formalizing some seemingly reasonable assumptions. Because intuitions are often the basic “data” of philosophy, especially in ethics, that is a problem. In contrast, the basic assumptions, or axioms, of a mathematical field are widely agreed upon by mathematicians, as are the basic definitions, and if an answer contradicts our intuitions, so much the worse for our intuitions (see Banach–Tarski paradox ). So these kind of difficulties that philosophers face don’t even come up and one can focus just on the chains of deductive or mathematical reasoning. This power of mathematics does come at a price, however, and that is that the scope of the questions it can answer is far, far more restricted than the scope of philosophical questions. You are not going to see a theory which attempts to determine the truth or falsity of a proposition like “action x is immoral” as a piece of mathematics because the very notion of morality is far richer and nuanced than can be handled just with mathematics. As with many things, there is a tradeoff here: you can increase your power in unequivocally finding the truth only at the expense of restricting yourself to subjects which make doing so feasible. Consequently, the goals of philosophers, as well as their subjects of investigation, are much more varied than those of mathematicians. Some philosophers may develop and defend a theory or ocasionally solve a problem in a way that the solution is universally agreed to be right, but more often their activities boil down to clarifying assumptions, identifying mistakes in reasoning or hidden assumptions in an argument, presenting counterexamples, framing a problem in a new way, identifying new aspects of a problem or simply just pose new problems. While mathematicians may do any of the above in the course of their work, their primary goal is to prove theorems.

I often read or read into one answer before I answer any digest questions. I read what Armin Nikkah Shirazi wrote: great answer. Here is my added 2¢: It was often remarked about earlier times (100’s of years ago) that there were only two major pursuits in the university: math and philosophy (both most often pursued together …think Pythagoras or much later, Descartes). I taught math in high school (US) and have a degree in Scholastic Philosophy. As a HS math teacher, I made it a point to also teach philosophy…even mysticism! I found ample points in all math, but especially geometry, to bring up philosophical questions. For instance, geometry is pretty much a system of definitions and provable theorems built upon undefinable terms and unprovable postulates or axioms. That alone gives one pause for philosophical thought. One of the undefined terms in geometry, the main one, is point. While we cannot define a point, be can describe it. One of the main descriptions of a point is that it does not take up space. Now, space is one of those terms that is definable. It is defined as the set of all points. We can easily gather from this that space is the set of all those things that do not take up space. WTF?! Space, as a not-so-mathematical concept, is what we all think of when we look at how much room a sofa will take up in our living room or where all the stars and galaxies reside. But, if we try to imagine space ending or not ending, we cannot, yet it seems it ought to be one or the other. If it is unending, it is inconceivable just as all infinities are. If it ends, well I will just stick my arm out and extend it by golly. Hmmm… One can hardly have a deeper thought than trying to conceive of these inconceivables - even if they get you nowhere. But, thinking deeply about things is what philosophy is all about. Not all efforts at deep or analytical thought get us nowhere. Math and philosophy each invite the other to share space. Their intersection will always be there. …oh, the question: what is the difference? I guess that might be up to each to answer. Here’s mine: since math can be purely conceptual in nature, pure mathematics or applied, applied mathematics. I would say that math is a part of philosophy as the philosophy of number. As it becomes applied, it becomes more its own branch of study. To understand this in a simple way, think of the number 2. No one has ever seen, heard, touched, tasted or heard the number two. But, we all have seen two people standing together. We have all seen it represented in written form, but that is only a representation, a symbol for the number 2.

A: They both deal with the same essential subject matter. But, only Philosophy puts value on Human Life — Maths does not.  Both - paradoxically - deal with the (very many) ‘non-objects’ that seem to ‘exist’ in the ‘objective world.’ Philosophy, however, distinctly asserts “the positive value of the human being” as an undeniable axiom at the start. Maths, however, remains resolutely unconcerned with the “human being” in-itself. Math only seems to care about how many of these supposedly “important” human beings there are.  Ironically enough, it is through Maths that we (human beings) discovered that many different things can be meant by “human being.” Among other things, Math has revealed to us, for example, that you could mean “one human being” or you could mean “all human beings.” (Or, frankly, you could even mean “somewhere in the middle.”) In other words, Maths helped Philosophy discover that one of its essential axioms has been left ill-defined. Are all human beings important? Are some human beings important? Or, is it that only one human being is important? And, most importantly, why?  P.S., It’s also possible that (what Rebecca Goldstein calls) ‘Philosophy-Jeerers’ are right. These might be those people who (initially) reject the undeniable axiom of philosophy — thus, deeming it ‘meaningless.’ They might skeptically ask: “are ‘human beings’ — whatever that means — important?” Since they do not “know” this themselves, they might look out at the world to uncover the answer. However, they might (somewhere down the line) “uncover an answer” from an external force; and, therefore, be ruled by an external force. One that is (by their own definition) not “objective;” but, rather, one that originates from a value-judgement that is not of their own (or, one of their own kind, to be frank). Viz., they might adopt the view that no human being — including themselves — is important. According to Math, this is merely a possible ‘truth.’ Philosophy, however, seems to elicit much (much) more emotional responses regarding the ‘truth’ of this claim. (Hint: Philosophy seems to elicit much (much) more human responses regarding the ‘truth’ of this claim.)

Philosophy deals with fundamental questions : It is an endless activity. Wittgenstein highlighted this aspect. Every culture in every age deals with the same questions again and again; Penrose is doing again now as what Plato was doing in his period. Every human being is doing philosophy in a fundamental sense. Mathematics : Primarily mathematics is arithmetic and geometry. This is the basic source of human activity. It has been repeatedly investigated in all levels leading to a definite body of knowledge and methods. Compare the kind of mathematical knowledge of Greek in Plato's time and current knowledge. Even a high school student may have more mathematical knowledge than Plato even in geometry and arithmetic. But if I compare Penrose and Plato as philosophers I will consider Penrose to fall short. This is one way to highlight the difference between philosophy and maths.

What is the difference between maths and philosophy? Maths is a symbolic language – one of two symbolic languages – the other is natural language. You can have philosophy without maths, but you cannot have maths without philosophy. Philosophy is more fundamental than maths. The most fundamental type of philosophy is metaphysics which is concerned with what exists and how we are able to know what exists. What this means in practice is defining the relationship between consciousness and reality. Defining this relationship is a substantial undertaking involving profound philosophical assumptions. But this definition is done using natural language and not using maths. Only when you have decided whether or not reality exists independently of consciousness, can you start using mathematics to describe it. You cannot do maths, until you have done some philosophy…

Well there are many. One would be that mathematics is a well established tool used to describe nature, philosophy is an abstract questioning of everything of nature itself. All mathematics are based on some axioms that are needed as a base to stand on. From there, you build up. Different areas of mathematics have different axioms to better describe different realities (from the Quantum realm to big numbers). Philosophy tries again and again to reset the foundations of thought and to identify what IS is.

The differences between math and philosophy are somewhat blurred. The same guy started both (Thales of Miletus) and since then they are inseparable. But we can say that the objects of interest in mathematics and its methods are more restricted than those of philosophy. Other statements about possible differences seem to me quite arbitrary.

Mathematics attempts to crystallize the mechanics of reason through the use of numbers and symbols. Philosophy attempts to do the same through the use of words and the ideas they reference. Both result from the use of a linear quantitative thought process as it finds form by way of the limitations that constitute us— its user. Hence, consciousness establishes the format for each, based upon how it is able to see itself. On the one hand it sees itself as a composite of difference that hints at a unity. On the other hand it sees itself as a unity comprised of difference. This is what separates the two — the order by which it prioritizes the two different ways it views reality stemming from its potential. Mathematics relies upon equality as its underlying principle. Philosophy relies on inequality. Both serve their purpose.

With maths, you start with axioms, which are basic statements that you consider true even if you can’t prove they are, and then you reason logically. Axioms are already expressed in mathematical language. Whether life is like that or not is not a problem for a mathematician. what matters is to reason properly. With philosophy, you start from life, and you try to figure out what it’s all about, and how you can argue to make a point to make it as valid as possible,and it’s messy because you try to talk about reality without being quite sure about what reality is.

Mathematics is philosophy. Philosophy is not mathematics. Mathematics is a very specific subset of philosophy. Philosophy is much more general, covering all aspects of reality (including unreal realities) and all aspects of thinking, including mathematics. Philosophy “the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence, especially when considered as an academic discipline.” Mathematics “the abstract science of number, quantity, and space” .

The difference isn’t as substantial as one thinks, since philosophy tends to be done now in a branch called Analytical Philosophy using the field of math called logic. However there appears to be a crucial distinction in that while math just says ‘Here are some of my rules, here are some results that follow’ but does not put a constraint on reality, philosophy ponders on reality itself from what is apparent, but does this purely through logic, where as science does this through empiricism and naturalistic assumptions.

The Greek word from which “mathematics” derives originally meant “that which can be taught.” Philosophy’s “love of wisdom” cannot be taught. Consequently, math is a system where the rules can be learned and where applications can be taught. Machines can be created to do math, and they are cranking out some fabulous results. Some have tried to correlate math with language and have thereby taught us more about the way we use language. Philosophers pay attention to such excursions. But language has subtleties that systems and machines cannot reproduce. So they are two different kinds of languages. Both worth learning.

Mathematics is a language for describing the quantifiable. Philosophy is a field of thought that focuses on qualifying the unquantifiable. In short, mathematics is about modeling phenomena and is used as an aid to scientific pursuit. It quantifies things in a descriptive way, but not just physical phenomena, it also has forms used in social modeling and even language studies themselves. Philosophy is also about modeling, and so often uses mathematics, but philosophy is all about the meaning behind the models, whereas mathematics is a tool used to structure the models. A high level of skill in mathematics and other languages is essential to the toolkit of the philosopher.

Philosophy (of mathematics) discusses existence of mathematical objects, meaning of mathematical vocabulary/usage, and methods of deduction. Mathematics proper is committed to a philosophical view (e.g., formalism, intuitionism) and to a particular ontology. It then uses formal tools to deduce theorems.

Mathematicians are usually Platonists, they believe that Mathematics is the best Philosophy ( I.e. Platonism). at all. This is a very old professional belief which official philosophers try to reject during last 2000 years.
Math gives me a headache, Philosophy cures the headache.

Both are religious subjects of science. What is revealed in maths end is clear, not so in philosophy as end may be rational, open, left in between so on..... Many possibilities in this but only method in maths to any solution.
Mathematics is about the relationships between objects and Philosophy is about the relationships between the physical and the metaphysical.
Philosophy serves to identify the right question. Without first doing that, you can’t solve the problem, regardless of the system used.
This question has already been once asked, and answered, on Quora: What is the difference between maths and philosophy?
What is the distance between 0 and 1, ‘1’ or ‘infinite’?
